transcript: Hi, my name is Will Borowski, and today I'm going to be showing you my Mini Project Three that I created. So, essentially, this is a saving goal investment recommendation generator. AI changes user experience by enabling greater personalization, faster problem-solving through automation, and more intuitive interactions. It also allows systems to anticipate the user's needs and deliver context-aware, highly relevant information and services, while also moving the experience from reactive to proactive. Then financial prompt engineering was challenging; that was primarily due to the need for extreme accuracy and reliability while dealing with sensitive and real-world monetary decisions. Ensuring that the AI's output adhered to complex and evolving regulatory compliance and accurately interpreted nuanced financial terminology under various market conditions required rigorous testing and iterative refinement. And then we get down to the main ethical concerns, and that's going to be bias and fairness in financial recommendations, ensuring that the tool doesn't perpetuate and amplify existing economic inequalities. Also, there's the challenge of transparency and accountability, making sure that users understand how the AI arrived at specific financial suggestions and what the limitations of the tool in general were. And then while trusting the tool with real money, while the underlying models are designed for high reliability, I wouldn't trust any current AI tool, including my own, with complete autonomy over real money without human oversight. The tools are best utilized as powerful assistants for analysis and suggestions, but the final, high-stakes decision on the deployment of real capital must remain with humans to mitigate the risk of unseen model failure or black swan events in the case of those. And yeah, these are my Version One and Version Two of my investment recommendation calculators using this AI. Thank you.
